data.title: World news, culture and opinion
data.meta_description: French Politics news: All the articles, features, photos and videos from Le Monde.
data.text:
In Depth Subscribers only

On the 80th anniversary of the Provence landings, Emmanuel Macron's African memorial headache

France's declining influence in Africa is reflected in the representation of the continent's states at commemorations of Operation Dragoon, which opened the southern front on August 15, 1944, with the massive participation of soldiers from the colonies.

Op-Ed Subscribers only

The French PM 'should be someone who is politically well-versed but sufficiently respected to transcend political divisions'

To prevent a vote of no confidence, the future prime minister should not seem like the president's ally or a potential presidential candidate and should advocate for the implementation of proportional representation.

In Depth Subscribers only

As Olympic 'political truce' ends, Macron's prime minister search resumes

Five weeks after the defeat of his camp in the second round of the legislative elections, the French president has still not appointed a successor to Gabriel Attal. He is expected to begin consultations in the week of August 19.

News

Olympic Games showed world 'the true face of France,' says Macron

'We don't want life to get back to normal,' President Emmanuel Macron said, the day after the closing ceremony.

Long Read Subscribers only

Left-wing candidate Lucie Castets' strange campaign for France's premiership

Over the two weeks since her name burst onto the French political scene, the Nouveau Front Populaire's candidate for prime minister has been thrust into the limelight and is trying to forge a reputation for herself.

Interview Subscribers only

Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo: 'These Games and the opening ceremony crush the far right's message'

The Socialist mayor of the French capital expressed joy and pride at the Games' success in an interview with Le Monde. She was also angry about the criticism of the city and her actions, behind which she sees the undermining work of the 'reactionary and far-right world'.

In Depth Subscribers only

Is France's Olympic joy only an intermission?

Since the opening of the Olympic Games, the French have shown their desire to share moments together. The country seems far away from the image of a divided society given off by the European and parliamentary elections only weeks ago.

News Subscribers only

Paris Olympics: Emmanuel Macron congratulates athletes and hopes for a 'legacy of pride'

On Friday, the President came to attend the Olympic events, as French athletes racked up medals. He aimed to get a sense of the country's enthusiasm, as it appears united and reconciled.

Column

Four French MPs and a deluge of hatred. Does anyone care?

Four radical-left MPs sat on a bench in the Assemblée Nationale on the first day of the new parliamentary session, and X users went wild. Le Monde's fashion columnist looked into the picture more closely.

In Depth Subscribers only

French audit court criticizes Elysée spending on receptions and trips

'Significant efforts will have to be undertaken, starting in 2024, in order to restore and perpetuate balance,' warned the state auditors, calling out an €8.3 million deficit in the French presidency's budget.

In Depth Subscribers only

Macron looks to use Olympic 'political truce' to hone his plan for a new prime minister

Emmanuel Macron is spending some time at the presidential holiday residence in southern France, still looking for a prime minister who could create consensus on both the left and right.

News Subscribers only

Paris shifts position and recognizes Morocco's sovereignty over Western Sahara

Risking a new crisis with Algeria, French President Emmanuel Macron wrote in a letter to king Mohammed VI, that the territory's future falls 'within the context of Moroccan sovereignty.'

News

Macron praises Olympics opening ceremony that made France 'extremely proud'

Speaking the day after France became the first Olympic host to take the opening ceremony out of a stadium, the French president said 'people told us this was impossible, but we did it thanks to your hard work.'

News Subscribers only

'Now, it's the Olympics': Macron declares 'political truce' but French government still on alert

France is officially kicking off the Paris 2024 Olympic Games. President Emmanuel Macron hopes that his idea of a 'political truce' will temporarily put aside the governmental crisis that has gripped the country over recent weeks.

Editorial

Macron's dangerous budget game

Weakened by his risky snap elections gamble, the president is dithering and the political scene is getting tenser by the day. This is problematic because if this wait-and-see situation were to degenerate into a budget crisis, the French would be the first to lose out.

In Depth Subscribers only

How the French left is preparing Lucie Castets, its surprise candidate for prime minister, to govern

The Paris City Hall's finance director has called on the president to 'take responsibility' by appointing her without delay. She also dismissed 'a coalition with the presidential camp' due to 'deep disagreements.'

In Depth Subscribers only

How France's left agreed on unknown civil servant Lucie Castets as candidate for prime minister

Deadlocked for 16 days, the Nouveau Front Populaire left-wing alliance avoided its own implosion by proposing the 37-year-old economist, the director of financial affairs at Paris City Hall, for prime minister. But President Emmanuel Macron immediately dismissed this option.

News Subscribers only

Macron postpones formation of new government until after Paris Olympics

The French president rejected the left's choice for prime minister, repeating that 'nobody won' the recent legislative elections. He said he does not want a new government before the end of the Games, on the pretext of 'stability.'

News

Key takeaways from Emmanuel Macron's interview

Just a few days before the opening of the Paris 2024 Olympics – and shortly after the Nouveau Front Populaire's proposal to appoint Lucie Castets as prime minister – the French president was the guest on France 2 and Radio France on Tuesday evening.

News

Macron offers 'welcome' to Israeli athletes for Paris Olympics

'We need to come together as France that is welcoming the world,' declared the French president during a live interview aired on French TV on Tuesday, July 23.

News

Macron says no new government until 'mid-August,' declining left-wing proposal for PM

The left-wing Nouveau Front Populaire alliance backed Lucie Castets, the finance director at Paris City Hall, to become France's prime minister. President Emmanuel Macron said he would not appoint a new prime minister until after the Paris Olympics.

Editorial

The need to rehabilitate French Parliament instead of subverting it

The president, by calling early elections, was hoping to "clarify" the political landscape, but only made it more complex. His weakened position is mirrored by the difficulty lawmakers have in assuming their responsibilities

Long Read Subscribers only

On the front lines of the far right's rise, France's rural mayors are in disarray

These mayors, who do not support the far-right Rassemblement National party, have constituents who have just elected its MPs in parliamentary elections. They waver between despondency and determination.

Long Read Subscribers only

France's left still struggles to find a candidate for prime minister

The left-wing Nouveau Front Populaire alliance leaders met again over the weekend. While previously suggested candidates, who have since backed down, were key to discussions, three new names were floated.

News

Which political groups make up France's new Assemblée Nationale?

Most MPs, elected or re-elected on July 7, chose a political group to sit with at the July 18 inaugural session.

In Depth Subscribers only

Bardella accumulates frustrations in European Parliament after failing to become French PM

The president of the far-right Rassemblement National party seems keen to be more involved in the upper echelons of European politics after being elected president of the Patriots for Europe group. But there are many pitfalls.

In Depth Subscribers only

A French billionaire's plan to 'enable victory' for the far right

With a €150 million investment and training courses for municipal candidates, conservative entrepreneur Pierre-Edouard Stérin has launched a project to help the far-right Rassemblement National and right-wing Les Républicains come to power.

Column Subscribers only

What's in a bag? How the tote became the Assemblée Nationale's new briefcase

While waiting for their chic leather briefcases, newly-elected MPs made their early return to Parliament in early July with a new kind of school bag: a cotton tote.

News

Paris 2024: Macron promises to swim in Seine, but 'not necessarily' before Olympics

The French president has said he would take a dip into the river's capital to reassure about the quality of the water. But he never set a date.

In Depth Subscribers only

Paris 2024: City's homeless 'made invisible' after camp evictions

Authorities have denied that camp closures are linked to the Olympics, but a collective of homeless organizations have expressed disappointment when it comes to the promise of a 'social legacy' from the Games.

Editorial

French elections: The risk of denying defeat

Since July 7, the presidential camp has been behaving as though it didn't lose the election.

Long Read Subscribers only

Anti-left front emerges as Macron-backed candidate re-elected as Assemblée Nationale president

Yaël Braun-Pivet, president of the Assemblée Nationale, was re-elected on Thursday against left-wing candidate André Chassaigne and far-right candidate Sébastien Chenu. She called for 'new methods'... just as she did in 2022.

In Depth Subscribers only

French left's failure to secure presidency of Assemblée is additional obstacle on road to power

The left-wing alliance's candidate, Communist André Chassaigne, lost to Yaël Braun-Pivet, who was re-elected thanks to the votes of the presidential camp and the right – a pattern that could be repeated with the post of prime minister.

News Subscribers only

Starmer and Macron make first move to 'restore relations' between London, Paris and the EU

Two weeks after his victory over the Tories, the new head of the British government took his first steps on the international stage by hosting the fourth summit of the European Political Community on Thursday.

News

Macron-supported candidate re-elected as Assemblée Nationale president

Yaël Braun-Pivet was reelected with 220 votes. In 2022, she became the first woman to be elected to this position.

Investigation Subscribers only

Luxury brands and private investors take over the Champs-Elysées

Ambitious real estate projects are on the rise up and down the famous avenue, with LVMH leading the charge. These companies want to make their mark on the street by funding an urban redevelopment plan.

News Subscribers only

In Strasbourg, refugees' anxiety heightened by advance of far right

In the eastern French city, a charity helps ease the psychological suffering of migrants with chaotic backgrounds. Their anguish has increased following the far right's results in recent elections.

Explainer

A glossary to understand the situation in French Parliament and government

France's snap elections have brought some procedural or technical terms back to the forefront: Parliamentary groups, presidency of the Assemblée, caretaker government... Le Monde explains them.

Explainer

Can Macron appoint anyone as prime minister? Is there a deadline for forming the government? Our answers to your French politics questions

Since the dissolution of the Assemblée and the snap elections, the French political situation has raised a number of questions, to which Le Monde attempts to provide some answers.

Editorial

The French left's procrastination on picking a prime minister threatens its new-found unity

Ten days of fruitless discussions between the leaders of the parties of the Nouveau Front Populaire have led to only one obvious conclusion: United and effective in the fight against the far right, the left loses all cohesion when it's on the doorstep of power.

Profile Subscribers only

Paris Mayor Hidalgo dives into the Seine and the Olympic deep end

With less than two years to go before the municipal elections, the mayor of Paris will benefit from the spotlight of the Olympic Games organized in the city, to which she made a major contribution. In her usual way.

In Depth Subscribers only

What economists say about the French left's policies

Le Monde asked a panel of experts about the three main measures proposed by the Nouveau Front Populaire left-wing coalition: lowering the retirement age, raising the minimum wage and taxing the richest. They were divided.

In Depth Subscribers only

New Caledonia's economy collapses after two months of insurrection

Already nearly bankrupt at the start of 2024, the New Caledonian government is facing massive unemployment caused by the destruction of businesses, shops and public infrastructure since the insurrection began on May 13.

Explainer

What are the powers of a caretaker government in France?

Prime Minister Gabriel Attal's government could remain in office for an indefinite period of time to handle day-to-day affairs, with restricted powers, until President Emmanuel Macron names a new prime minister.

News

Macron accepts PM's resignation, government shifts to caretaker role

President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Gabriel Attal's government, which will now remain only in a caretaker capacity.

Editorial

France's two debts and the risk of collective denial

The financial and climate debts pose a common threat: a loss of control. The significant increase of the deficit to 5.5% of GDP has already had a lasting effect and could disrupt the entire budget plan leading up to 2027.

In Depth Subscribers only

What is happening in French Parliament this week?

With no government and no majority, members of the freshly elected Assemblée Nationale will have to elect the chamber's president and other top jobs in an unprecedented context.

In Depth Subscribers only

France's startups concerned over effects of Macron's snap elections

The French FinTech community, strongly backed by French President Emmanuel Macron, is worried about the changing image of the country and its president among foreign investors.

In Depth Subscribers only

Far-right RN carries out discreet purge after electoral failure

The Rassemblement National has dismissed several members who proved to be xenophobic, racist or anti-Semitic during the election campaign.

News

French left back to square one as proposed PM 'declines' role

Huguette Bello, who was backed by the Communists and La France Insoumise, crucially did not have the support of the Socialists.

Column Subscribers only

French elections: 'The republican reflex against the far right shows the power of anti-racism'

The relief of the RN's temporary sidelining should not overshadow the public outpouring of racism aroused by the prospect of its coming to power, warns Le Monde columnist Philippe Bernard.

Investigation Subscribers only

Meet the far-right French MPs elected despite racist, anti-abortion or climate-skeptic stances

Twenty-one new or returning MPs who have taken radical positions will serve in the Assemblée Nationale for Marine Le Pen's Rassemblement National party.

News

French Socialists refuse to endorse former communist MP Huguette Bello as prime minister

The president of the regional council of La Réunion has received the backing of the Communists and hard-left LFI leader Jean-Luc Mélenchon. The Socialists put forward several arguments against Bello, such as the fact that she did not take part in the vote on the law on same-sex marriage in 2013.

Column Subscribers only

Thomas Piketty: 'It's time for the left to get back to describing the alternative economic system to which it aspires'

In his column, the economist advises the French left to create a democratic federation capable of organizing deliberation and settling disputes, rather than wallowing in rhetorical radicalism.

In Depth Subscribers only

As French left looks for a prime minister, an unexpected name emerges

Huguette Bello, the president of the regional council of La Réunion, an overseas territory in the Indian Ocean, has received the backing of the Communists, the Greens and Jean-Luc Mélenchon. But the Socialists still want their leader to be the left's candidate to form a government.

News Subscribers only

NATO summit: Macron returns to 'center of the photo' for 36 hours

In Washington, the French president boasted to his allies about sidelining his foreign policy opponents in France. However, returning to Paris, where his letter to the French has been criticized, will be more challenging.
